name: Behind the Scenes of ConnecTeen
description: A volunteer is going through the application and recruitment process for the ConnecTeen program and goes through a series of events that gets them to supporting another youth in crisis. (i.e. You are so stoked as you have been looking forward to volunteering with ConnecTeen when you turned 15 years old. You have been in crisis before and have used the service in the past to get through some dark times and now that you are feeling better you want to support others who are going through the same thing. The application and recruitment process is a lot more extensive than you originally thought and it's taken you about 2 and a half months before you could even take your first solo shift. Now that you are on your first shift, a youth tells you they are at risk for suicide - how will you support the youth in your new role?

introduction_data.header_text: Behind the Scenes of ConnecTeen Escape Room

conclusion_data.header_text: Great job, you escaped the Behind the Scenes of ConnecTeen Escape Room! Thank you for playing! You were able to find ways prepare for the application process and were able to start the coaching shifts. Below are some take away points from the escape room. To learn more about ConnecTeen please visit our website here.
conclusion_data.paragraph_text:
By solving the puzzles and going through the room, you have learnt important skills such as 
making sure to fully read all the information that relates to any job or volunteer description as well as dressing the part (especially for the interview). Don't forget to always check if a new commitment fits within your schedule. It's great to interact with other participants, they might be your fellow volunteers in training process. Being able to refer back to what you have learned about in the volunteer descriptions as well as being able to pull from your own experiences can help show you are engaging with the material and you've done your own research. It's okay to ask questions and it's okay to use the material we give you! Everyone starts a different points in their learning process.
As important as it is to be able to absorb the learning material it's also just as important to make sure that you are okay! We can't take care of others if we ourselves are struggling - self care is so important! Just like how we are learning to communicate to those in crisis and support them we should also make sure we are communicating to everyone who is there to support you on a shift (i.e. coaches, CCC's, training coordinators, youth program coordinators). It's always scary to start something new, the important part is that you are trying and you've taken the steps to prepare. We all gotta start somewhere!

data.text: It's been 2 years since you've used the service and now that you've turned 15 years old you're getting ready to apply to be a volunteer as you want to give back to the agency that helped you through some tough times.
Nice, now that you've made sure to look at all the information to apply you're ready to submit your application.
You were contacted after you submitted your application and now will be participating in a group interview - scary!!
You'll be providing support to someone acting as a service user to show your level current understanding of crisis support. Let's take a breath and try your best!

It's now your turn to go. You take a deep breath and remember some of the qualities they look for in a volunteer as well as the type of support you were provided when you used the service in the past.
You did your best to support the acting service user and were given some areas of strength and areas of feedback afterwards.

You made it past the group interviews!! Nice! Now you're in training and want to make sure you are participating and engaging in the material as much as you can while also getting to know the other applicants.
You will be doing more roleplays in training so that you can practice providing crisis support. There are tons of processes to get into this volunteer role and you want to do your best to pass!

It's your turn to complete a roleplay! You take out some diagrams and notes they gave to help give you tips when it comes to completing the roleplays. You do your best to be as independent as possible while also making use of the material when you feel stuck. Roleplay complete - phew !

You've finished training and now you get to go on to coaching shifts! Coaching shifts is where you can support real service users while being coached by a Leadership Volunteer as well as getting support from the CCC (supervisor).
There are a few things you need to prepare before you can actually take some contacts. Take a deep breath and let's get started on set up!
You take out your water bottle, it's filled with your favorite drink so that you can get comfortable. You stretch as well to get the nerves off and breath deeply.

You remembered that you also talked to the Youth Program Coordinator before the shift to talk about how you're feeling to get some support and be able to vocalize your emotions. You're ready to take a contact!
Your Coach comes in and introduces themselves. They're impressed at how prepared you are for the shift!

You two talk about your goals, feelings, areas of strength and areas of development to get to know you a bit more. After chatting for a bit a contact comes in and now it's your chance to put everything you know into practice!

You opened the chat!!! Your heart is racing and see that the service user has said something. You take another breath, the Coach and CCC smile at you for reassurance. You begin typing up your response!
